Triggering Event:
A nurse, barely out of diapers, sauntered up to me during my rounds, "Dr. H., the new interns asked if you could show them how to use the old ECG machine again? They said it's 'too analog' for them."

I felt a bitter laugh bubble up, but I swallowed it down. *Too analog, my ass.* I'd been reading ECGs by hand since before these kids were born. *And now they want me to hold their hands because it's "too old school"?*

"Fine," I snapped, "I'll show them how it works. Again." As if I didn't have real patients to see, real lives to save.

I stormed into the supply closet where they'd set up the ancient machine, a relic from my early days. It was like seeing an old friend, but today, it just made me angrier. *This is what I get for trying to keep history alive,* I thought, wiping away a bitter tear. *A bunch of kids who can't be bothered to learn how to use something that's not connected to the cloud.*
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, those new interns think they're so much better than everyone else just because they've got fancy gadgets and cloud-connected everything. Newsflash: just because it's newer doesn't mean it's automatically better. I swear, I've seen some of these kids walk into the hospital with their noses buried in their phones, completely oblivious to the world around them.

And don't even get me started on this ECG machine nonsense. Who needs all those bells and whistles when you've got a tried-and-true method that's worked for decades? I mean, seriously, do they really need to know how to read an actual electrocardiogram? Can't they just rely on some algorithm or whatever?

It's just so frustrating, watching these young doctors come in here thinking they know it all. Like, hello, we've been doing this for years! We've got the experience, the knowledge, and the skills. What do they bring to the table? A few fancy degrees and a whole lot of attitude?

I'm telling you, it's like they think they're above all this. Above learning from someone who actually knows what they're doing. Above respecting the tradition and expertise that's been built over the years. No, instead they just want to rush in, wave their magic wand, and expect everything to magically work itself out.

And the worst part is, they're going to go out there and make mistakes. Big ones. Because they're too busy playing with their toys to actually pay attention to what's going on. And then they're going to wonder why things aren't working out the way they planned. Well, let me tell you, it's not because of us old-timers. It's because they're just not paying attention.

I swear, sometimes I feel like I'm stuck in some kind of medical time warp. Watching these kids come in here, thinking they're the first ones to ever pick up a stethoscope or read an ECG. It's like, hello, we've been doing this for centuries! You'd think they'd at least have the decency to learn from our experiences.

But no, instead they just want to reinvent the wheel. To prove that they're somehow better than everyone else. Well, let me tell you, it's not about being better. It's about getting the job done. And right now, they're not doing it very well.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the quiet of his small apartment, Harold shuffled towards the window, his slippers whispering against the worn carpet. The sun had dipped below the horizon, casting long shadows that danced with the flickering streetlights. He liked this time of day best; it was when the world seemed to hold its breath, mirroring his own silent despair.

His reflection in the glass looked back at him, a man carved from years and sorrow. His once-dark hair now sported wisps of silver, and his eyes, behind thick glasses, held a perpetual sadness. He traced the edge of the frame with a gnarled finger, remembering how Marie used to tease him about his "old man glasses."

The phone rang, its shrill tone piercing the silence. Harold hesitated, then picked up the receiver. "Hello?" His voice was barely above a whisper.

"Hi, Dad." It was his daughter, Emily. Her voice sounded distant, tinny through the poor connection. "I've got some news."

Harold braced himself, waiting for whatever blow life would deal him next. "What is it, dear?"

There was a pause, then Emily sighed. "It's... it's about the house, Dad. I've been thinking, and... well, I think it might be best if we sold it."

Harold felt a coldness spread through him. The house. Their house. Marie's house. He hadn't been back since the funeral. It was too full of memories, too empty without her. "Sold?" he echoed, his voice barely audible.

"Yes," Emily said gently. "It's just... too much for me to handle alone, Dad. And it could give you a fresh start."

Fresh start? Harold thought bitterly. How could there be a fresh start when everything reminded him of Marie? Of their life together? He felt a familiar tightness in his chest, a despair that seemed to choke the very air from his lungs.

"I... I'll think about it, Emily," he managed to say before hanging up.

He returned to the window, staring out into the night. The world seemed even darker now, more desolate than before. His reflection stared back at him, accusing, sad. He felt a tear slide down his cheek, unnoticed and unwanted. Another day without Marie was beginning, another night of endless despair.
Generated Assessment:
This conversation is just another nail in the coffin. My daughter thinks she can just sell our home, the place where Marie and I built our life together? It's like she's trying to erase everything we had. I swear, sometimes I feel like I'm drowning in a sea of grief, and she's just throwing me a lifeline made of broken promises.

How can she expect me to move on? This house is all I have left of her. Every room, every corner, every memory is etched into my brain like a scar. And now she wants to rip it all away? No, thank you. I'd rather stay here, surrounded by the ghosts of our past, than face the uncertainty of a new life without Marie.

And what's with this "fresh start" nonsense? Does she really think I need some magical solution to make me forget? Forget the pain, forget the loss, forget the love we shared? I don't think so. I know exactly what I need – I need to hold onto the memories, to cling to the past, because that's all I have left.

Emily thinks she's doing the right thing, but she has no idea what she's getting herself into. She's just going to regret this decision, mark my words. I'll make sure of it. I'll find a way to stop her, to keep our home safe from those who would seek to destroy it. Because when it comes to our family's history, I won't let anyone take that away from me. Not even my own daughter.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event: "Hey, you know who I saw today? That blasted kid from the neighborhood, the one who used to follow me around like a lost puppy after my Harry passed. He's got a job now, can you believe it? At the very store where I've been slaving away for decades! And guess what they gave him? The manager position. The nerve! Here I am, busting my ass every damn day, and they hand over the reins to some whippersnapper who wouldn't know customer service if it bit him on his entitled little butt. You'd think after all these years, they'd show a lick of respect, but noooo. It's always the same old story - 'Thanks for your service, Edna. Here's your minimum wage and a pat on the back.' Well, screw them. And screw that kid too. I'm not lifting a finger to help him learn the ropes. Let him figure it out himself. It serves them right if he drives customers away with his 'manager' attitude."
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, I just can't even deal with some people anymore. Like, I was talking to my coworker, Karen, about our boss, and she mentioned how nice it was that John had gotten the new promotion. Nice? Are you kidding me? I know he thinks he's so much better than everyone else just because he's got a fancy title. Newsflash, John: having a degree doesn't make you special. And don't even get me started on how he's always trying to one-up everyone else. I swear, he's got a personal vendetta against our team. I mean, I've seen the way he looks at us - like we're inferior or something. And now he's going to come in here and try to tell us how to do our jobs? Please. I'll believe it when I see it.

And another thing, why does he have to be so condescending? I mean, I know he thinks he's helping by explaining things to us, but really, he's just patronizing us. Like, hello, we're adults, we can handle our own work. But no, he has to go and talk down to us like we're children. It's just so...so...infuriating. I'm surprised he hasn't tried to take credit for our ideas yet. I mean, it's only a matter of time before he starts stealing our thunder. Mark my words.

I just wish someone would call him out on this behavior already. You know, someone who actually knows what's going on behind the scenes. Not just some clueless manager who thinks he's above it all. But no, instead we get stuck with John, the self-absorbed know-it-all who thinks he's God's gift to management. Well, let me tell you, John, you're not as smart as you think you are. And I'm not afraid to say it.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the sterile quiet of the hospital kitchen, where she'd found solace for decades, Margaret slammed her lunch bag onto the counter. She hadn't meant to make such a racket, but today it felt good, a release valve for the pressure building inside her.

She was tired, so very tired. Tired of the endless shift changes, the whispered complaints about staffing cuts. Tired of watching her colleagues struggle with heavier workloads and less support than they'd had in their prime. But what irked her most, what set her teeth on edge, was the memory of yesterday's incident.

Young Dr. Harper, fresh-faced and confident, had breezed into the nurses' station, demanding Margaret's presence at his side for an emergency surgery. An emergency? More like a last-minute change of heart from a panicked patient. Margaret had seen it all before, but she'd gone, as she always did.

But then he'd dismissed her, mid-surgery, with a curt, "We'll take it from here." As if she were just another pair of hands, not a seasoned nurse who'd delivered countless lives into this world. She'd stood there, in her scrubs stained with someone else's blood, feeling small and foolish.

And now, here she was, standing in the kitchen, watching as Dr. Harper poured himself a coffee, laughing with his colleagues about something that wasn't even funny. Bitterness clawed at her throat. They didn't know what it meant to work hard, to truly care for their patients. They were just children playing dress-up.

Margaret grabbed her lunch bag, storming out of the kitchen before she could say something she'd regret. She was done being taken for granted. Done being overlooked. It was time they remembered who the real backbone of this hospital was.
Generated Assessment:
As I watched Dr. Harper prance around the hospital, I couldn't help but think: What if he gets sued for malpractice? What if one of those patients dies under his watch? What if the hospital loses its license because of his reckless decisions?

I mean, seriously, how can he just dismiss me like that? Don't they know I've been doing this for decades? Don't they care that I'm the one who keeps this place running smoothly while they're off gallivanting around, making life-or-death decisions?

And what if they don't have anyone else to cover for him when he's too busy sipping lattes with his friends? What if the ER collapses and they're left scrambling to find someone, anyone, to pick up the pieces?

It's not like I'm paranoid or anything, but what if... what if... what if... Ugh, my head is spinning just thinking about it.

I swear, sometimes I feel like I'm the only adult in this room. The rest of them are just a bunch of naive kids playing doctor, completely oblivious to the reality of the job.

Dr. Harper thinks he's so smart, doesn't he? Thinks he can just waltz in here and start making decisions without consulting anyone? Well, let me tell you, he's got a lot to learn. And I'm going to make sure everyone knows it.

I'm not being dramatic, I'm just being realistic. What if... what if... what if... Oh wait, I forgot. Nobody ever listens to me anyway. Might as well just go ahead and assume the worst-case scenario. That's probably what will happen anyway.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the gloaming of a Tuesday, as rain spatters against the windows like Nature's own typing error, Thomas found himself ensconced in his study, a glass of single malt whiskey his sole companion. The ticking of the antique clock on the mantel was deafening, each second echoing with the mockery of time wasted.

His eyes, bloodshot from years of late nights and early mornings, scanned the yellowed newspaper clippings adorning the wall. Each one a testament to a story well told, yet each now seemed like a tombstone marking his missed chances. The award for "Best Investigative Journalist" gathering dust on the bookshelf might as well have been a participation trophy.

Thomas swirled the amber liquid in his glass, watching it cling to the sides with a tenacity he wished he'd shown in his younger years. His reflection stared back at him from the polished surface, lines etched deeper by regret than time itself could carve.

His partner of two decades, Elizabeth, had been right all along. He should have taken that sabbatical when she suggested it, should have spent more time with their children while they were still young enough to care. Instead, he'd chosen the adrenaline rush of deadline chases and the camaraderie of newsroom smokes over family dinners.

Now, his daughter was engaged to a man Thomas had never met, and his son barely returned his calls. And Elizabeth...well, she'd left him. Not in the dramatic sense, but rather like a slow leak in an old tire, until one day there was nothing left but empty space between them.

Thomas downed the remainder of his drink, welcoming the burn that threatened to consume him. It was preferable to the gnawing regret that clung to him like a second skin. He reached for the bottle, only to find it empty. Typical, he thought bitterly, even the whiskey had abandoned him.

With a sigh that seemed to echo through every corner of the silent house, Thomas stood up, the weight of his regrets heavier than any Pulitzer Prize could ever be. He turned off the lights, plunging himself into darkness, and made his way upstairs to an empty bed and another sleepless night haunted by the ghosts of chances missed.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, what a damn Tuesday. I swear, the universe is just trolling me today. First, the rain starts pounding against the windows like some kind of cruel joke. Can't even enjoy a simple evening at home without feeling like I'm stuck in some kind of prison.

And don't even get me started on my career. That stupid newspaper clipping on the wall? Yeah, it's just a reminder of all the opportunities I blew because I was too busy chasing deadlines. I mean, who needs personal growth or relationships when you can have a fancy award, right?

My partner, Rachel, always said I needed to take a break, spend more time with the kids. But no, I had to go and chase after some big scoop instead. Now look where we are - our kids barely talk to me, and Rachel's gone. Like, what did I do wrong? Did I really mess everything up so badly?

And now this? My daughter's getting married to some guy I've never even met. What's the point of even having kids if they're just going to grow up and leave me behind? I feel like I've failed everyone. Failed myself.

Why does everything always have to fall apart around me? Can't anyone else see how messed up things are? Is it just me, or does everyone else seem to be living their best life while I'm stuck in this rut?

I need a drink. Or five. This damn whiskey's probably the only thing that can numb the pain long enough for me to face reality. But even that's not working anymore. It's like the whole world has turned against me.

I'm done trying to make excuses. I'm done blaming everyone else. It's time to own up to my mistakes and deal with the consequences. But honestly, what's the point? I'll just end up hurting someone else anyway. Ugh, why can't I just get it together for once?!<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the quietude of his study, Dr. Harold Thompson, 64, was engrossed in the meticulous task of cataloging his life's work - a collection of scientific papers dating back decades. His wife, Martha, had long since retired from her own academic pursuits, but Harold continued toiling away, driven by an insatiable curiosity and a melancholic sense of duty.

As he carefully placed each article into its designated folder, he noticed with growing annoyance that several were missing. He counted them thrice over, his brow furrowing deeper each time. This was not the first instance of such an occurrence; his beloved library had been falling into disarray for some time now.

With a heavy sigh, Harold rose from his chair and made his way to Martha's study next door. He found her engrossed in a novel, her glasses perched precariously on the tip of her nose. She looked up as he entered, smiling softly.

"Harold, dear," she greeted, "what is it?"

"I've noticed several of my papers are missing again," Harold replied, his voice tinged with mild irritation. "I've counted them three times - they're definitely gone."

Martha's smile faded slightly, replaced by a look of contrition. "Oh, Harold, I'm sorry," she said, closing her book. "I must have moved them while looking for something else. You know how my eyes are these days; I can't see half the titles anymore."

Harold let out another sigh, this one laced with melancholy. He knew Martha meant no harm, but her absent-mindedness was becoming increasingly frustrating. His once-pristine sanctuary now bore the hallmarks of their advancing years - disorder, forgetfulness, and a creeping sense of decay.

"I'll help you find them," Martha offered, standing up. "We'll sort through everything together."

Harold nodded, grateful for her effort but feeling a pang of sadness nonetheless. As they began their search side by side, he couldn't shake the feeling that they were not just looking for lost papers, but also trying to hold onto the order and purpose of their past lives.
Generated Assessment:
The futility of our endeavors is already apparent. It's only a matter of time before the entire collection is reduced to nothing more than a pile of scattered pages and forgotten dreams. The fact that we're even bothering to search for the missing articles is a futile exercise in desperation.

As we sift through the chaos that has become our library, I am reminded of the countless hours we've wasted on this Sisyphean task. The papers will never be found, and even if they were, what would be the point? They're just relics of a bygone era, reminders of a time when our minds were sharper and our focus more keen.

Martha's efforts, though well-intentioned, are ultimately doomed to fail. Her lack of attention to detail is a symptom of a larger problem – a decline in mental acuity that cannot be reversed. We're not just searching for lost papers; we're fighting against the inevitable tide of forgetfulness that will soon engulf us both.

The thought of our once-tidy sanctuary now descending into complete disarray is almost too much to bear. The very fabric of our reality is unraveling before our eyes, and yet we press on, driven by a masochistic determination to cling to the past. It's a losing battle, and we both know it.

As we continue this futile quest, I am struck by the realization that our lives are but a series of incremental declines, each step further down the path of irrelevance. The missing papers are merely a harbinger of the greater calamity that awaits us all – a world where knowledge is lost, and wisdom is forgotten.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Emma, 31, a software engineer, was stuck in yet another meeting that had spun out of control. She'd been at it for hours, her eyes glazing over as she watched the presentation slides blur into one another. Her fingers tapped an impatient rhythm on her keyboard, the sound echoing in the silent Zoom room like a metronome counting down to detonation.

The speaker, a senior executive who insisted on leading every discussion despite his lack of technical prowess, was droning on about "synergistic growth" and "paradigm shifts." Emma could feel her blood pressure rising with each buzzword. She'd heard it all before, but today, it felt like nails on a chalkboard.

She tried to focus on the task at hand, a complex coding issue she was supposed to be tackling. But every time she opened her code editor, the meeting's noise seeped in, making it impossible to concentrate. She felt her chest tighten, her temples throbbing in sync with her tapping fingers.

Her boyfriend, Alex, had messaged earlier, asking if she wanted to grab dinner after work. She'd replied with a thumbs-up, but now, looking at the clock, she realized that "after work" was becoming an elusive concept. Another hour ticked by as they debated whether to rename a project from "Project Alpha" to "Project Bravo." Emma felt her frustration boil over.

"I've got a ticket to solve," she snapped, silencing the room. She muted herself and threw her headphones onto the desk, letting out a sigh that was part relief, part exasperation.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, I'm so done with this meeting. It feels like we're just going through the motions. The guy's talking about synergy and paradigm shifts, but honestly, what does he even know? He's just spewing buzzwords like they're going out of style.

And don't even get me started on the code. I swear, I've been staring at these lines for hours, trying to make sense of them. But no matter how hard I try, my brain just won't cooperate. It's like my mind is a sieve, letting all the important stuff slip right through.

I mean, seriously, can't we just rename Project Alpha to Project Bravo already? It's not like it's going to change the world. And what's with the executive's obsession with "disrupting the status quo"? Like, dude, we're not exactly living in the Wild West here.

I'm starting to lose my patience. I need a drink. Or three. This meeting is sucking the life out of me. And to think, I was looking forward to grabbing dinner with Alex tonight. Now, I'm not even sure if I'll make it home in time.

Why do I always get stuck with the boring meetings? Can't someone else take the reins for once? Ugh, I hate when this happens. Just great, now I'm going to be late for dinner...<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the quiet hum of the quaint little boutique where she'd faithfully served for decades, Mildred found herself in an unusual predicament. A young woman, barely out of her teens and dressed in an outfit that was more provocative than practical, had entered the store earlier that morning. Mildred, with her silver hair neatly coiffed under a pristine hairnet, greeted the girl warmly, as she did every customer. The young woman, however, seemed to have eyes only for the glittering baubles in the display case.

"Could I see that brooch, please?" she asked, pointing at an exquisite piece that Mildred herself had admired from afar. "The one with the rubies."

Mildred obliged, carefully removing the delicate item from its velvet nest and placing it on a plush cushion for inspection. The girl picked up the brooch, turning it this way and that, her fingers tracing the intricate filigree.

"It's beautiful," she breathed, looking up at Mildred with eyes sparkling more brightly than any gemstone. "It must be worth a fortune."

Mildred felt a swell of pride. "Yes, it is quite valuable," she agreed. "A family heirloom, passed down through generations."

The girl's eyes widened. "Wow, you mean like... royalty?" she gasped dramatically.

Mildred chuckled softly. "Not quite, dear. But it does have quite the history," she said, launching into a tale of her beloved boutique and its treasures, as she had done countless times before.

Just as she was reaching the climax of her story, the girl suddenly dropped the brooch onto the counter with a resounding clatter. "Oh my gosh, that's so boring!" she exclaimed, rolling her eyes heavenward. "You must be, like, the oldest person alive if you've been here forever!"

Mildred felt as though she'd been struck by one of the store's thunderbolts from its ancient lightning rod. Her cheeks flamed with humiliation as she watched the girl saunter out of the boutique, leaving behind an echoing silence that seemed to mock her every word.

"It appears I've been quite rude," Mildred muttered under her breath, carefully retrieving the brooch and examining it for any signs of damage. "I do hope Her Majesty will forgive me."
Generated Assessment:
The indignity of it all still lingers, a bitter aftertaste that refuses to dissipate. That impudent child, with her garish attire and vacant expression, had the audacity to dismiss my life's work with such callous disregard. My years of dedication, my unwavering commitment to this humble boutique, reduced to nothing more than a tedious anecdote, a relic of a bygone era.

As I stood there, frozen in shock, my mind racing with the implications of her words, I couldn't help but feel a sense of validation. Yes, perhaps I am indeed the oldest person alive, clinging to a bygone era, refusing to adapt to the whims of the modern world. And yet, how could anyone truly appreciate the beauty of tradition, the value of preserving the past?

That girl, with her fleeting attention span and shallow understanding, had no concept of the rich history that surrounded her. She saw only the surface, the glitz and glamour, never stopping to consider the depth, the substance. And I, foolishly, had allowed myself to be swayed by her opinions, to doubt my own worth.

But now, as I stand amidst the silence, the echoes of her dismissal still ringing in my ears, I realize the truth. I am not just a relic of the past; I am a guardian of tradition, a keeper of the flame. And those who would seek to extinguish it, to reduce it to nothing more than a footnote in the annals of time, are simply not worthy of its radiance.

In the end, it is not I who has been rude, but rather the world itself, which has failed to recognize the value of my contributions. And so, I shall continue to tend the fire, to nurture the embers, even as the winds of change howl around me, threatening to snuff out the light. For I know that, in the end, it is not the world that will be left standing, but the traditions, the values, and the timeless beauty that they represent.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the heart of her studio, she stood before the canvas, a landscape in progress - or so it once was. Her trembling hands, palsied by age and anxiety, had dripped paint onto the floorboards like bloody tears. She could scarcely believe what she'd done; years of labor reduced to this humiliation.

Her partner of five decades entered quietly, carrying a tray with tea and biscuits, his eyes crinkling gently behind his glasses. "Still at it, I see," he said, setting down the tray. His voice was warm, encouraging, but she bristled nonetheless.

"It's ruined!" she snapped, her cheeks flaming with embarrassment. She gestured wildly at the marred canvas, paint flecking off her fingers like dried skin. "I'm ruined! I can't do this anymore!"

He reached out tentatively, perhaps to console or redirect, but she swatted his hand away. "Don't touch me!" she spat, recoiling as if he were a serpent. "You don't understand! You never have!"

His face fell like a stone into still water, and the room seemed to grow colder around them. She watched him leave, his shoulders slumped in defeat, and felt the weight of her humiliation settle heavier upon her heart. The door clicked shut behind him, sealing her away with her failure.

She turned back to the canvas, hands trembling anew as she reached for a cloth. "I'll clean it up," she whispered, defeated. "I'll start again." But the words rang hollow in her ears, echoing through the studio like mocking laughter.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, why bother even trying? I swear, my art has been a disaster since I started painting. Every single piece I've ever made has ended up like this – a mess, a catastrophe, a complete and utter failure. My partner tries to tell me it's okay, that everyone has bad days, but does he know how hard it is to get the colors right when your hands are shaking like leaves?

And don't even get me started on the state of my studio. It's a war zone, a battlefield where creativity goes to die. I mean, seriously, who needs all these canvases and paints and brushes when they're just going to end up covered in globs of paint and splattered everywhere? It's like I'm some kind of clumsy oaf, incapable of even holding a brush without making a mess.

My partner says I need to relax, that I'm putting too much pressure on myself, but does he know what it's like to be a perfectionist? To want every stroke of the brush to be perfect, every color to be just right? No, he doesn't. He's just some clueless guy who thinks I'm being dramatic, that I need to toughen up.

But it's not just about the art, it's about the principle. If I let myself make mistakes, if I let myself fail, then what's the point of even trying? I might as well just give up now and save myself the trouble. And besides, if my partner can't even support me, then maybe I shouldn't bother trying to make him happy either.

I'll just clean up this mess and start over, because that's what losers do. They just keep getting back up, no matter how many times they fall. Well, I'm a loser, and I'll just keep losing until I finally get it right. Or until I run out of paint. Whichever comes first.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event: "Hey there, Mr. Thompson," Principal Harris barked from his office doorway, "Gotta second to go over tomorrow's parent-teacher night schedule?" Your stomach lurched like you'd swallowed a live squirrel. You hadn't even thought about that damn event. You forced a grin, "Sure thing, boss. Let's do this." As he launched into the rundown, your mind raced. What if parents ask about little Johnny's grades? Or worse, his behavior? You could feel the sweat starting to bead on your forehead. Keep it together, man. It's just parent-teacher night. Right? Fuck me gently with a chainsaw, it was gonna be a long week.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, I'm telling you, every single parent-teacher night is a disaster waiting to happen. The minute those doors open, chaos erupts. Parents will be breathing down my neck, questioning everything from Johnny's grades to his behavior. They'll be nitpicking every little detail, never satisfied with anything. And don't even get me started on the teachers - they're all just going to stand there, smiling and pretending like everything is fine when it's clearly not. I swear, it's always the same story. The parents will be rude, the teachers will be incompetent, and I'll be stuck in the middle, trying to keep everyone happy. It's a nightmare, and I know it's going to be a whole lot worse than I can handle.<|eot_id|>
